required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Analyze Changes in Respiratory Rate When Using the Scare Respirator
clinical_study.official_title: Pilot Study of Using the Scare Respirator: Effect on Synchronicity, Respiratory Rate, Heart Rate, Oxygen Saturation, Neonatal-Infant Pain Scale (NIPS) and Sleep-wake Cycle on Amplitude Electroencephalography( aEEG)

brief_summary.textblock: Pilot study of 20 newborns, 10 term and 10 preterm, who are going to be placed to 3 phases : 2 hour of basal observation of respiratory rate, heart rate, saturation, NIPS and aEEG recording, then 2 hours with a 20cycles/minute with "scare ventilator", and followed for another 2 hours of 40 cycles/minute with "scare ventilator"

detailed_description.textblock:
With this pilot study the investigator's want to see if the "scare respirator" can modify the vital signs of the newborn (NB) and if there is a relationship according to the frequency per minute given by the scare respirator and the patient's respiratory rate.
The "scare respirator" has been used many times to prevent central apnea in the newborn. This involves using a mechanical ventilator, but instead of connecting it to the patient's trachea to inflate his lungs, the air flow is connected to a surgical glove that inflates and deflates, with the optimal respiratory rate that the patient should have. This will be placed on the back to stimulate it tactically giving the necessary impulse of inspiration so that the patient alone can acquire the movement.
The importance of the development of this study is that it has been seen that the "scare respirator" could avoid central apneas, but no studies have been done on the change in respiratory rate that occurs with the device or if it bothers the NB or alters its wakefulness sleep pattern.
It is intended to evaluate 20 NBs, 10 term children and 10 premature infants, during 3 observation periods. Heart rate (HR), Respiratory rate (RR) and saturation, pain scale and aEEG sleep wake pattern will be evaluated; first a rest period between feeds as baseline, then with a scare respirator at 20 cycles per minute and finally at 40 cycles per minute. The differences of qualitative and quantitative variables will be assessed with ad-hoc statistical tests.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: 10 term newborns and 10 preterms are going to be put on sequential measures in 2 hours blocks of, no intervention first, followed by 2 hours of scare ventilator setted at 20 cycles per minute, and after that, 2 hours of scare ventilator at 40cycles per minute

primary_outcome.measure: Change of respiratory Synchronicity with the scare ventilator between 20 and 40 cycles per minute (cpm)
primary_outcome.time_frame: ten minutes after each intervention starts and every ten minutes for 2 hours straight
primary_outcome.description: % of time were respiratory rate is synchronised with the scare ventilator input, two tales of statistical differences, at 20 and 40 cycles per minute (cpm)

secondary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline newborn HR using the scare ventilator at 20 cpm
secondary_outcome.time_frame: pre-intervention, ten minutes after intervention starts and every ten minutes for 2 hours straight
secondary_outcome.description: differences in HR mean with two tales of statistical analysis ,between the two study periods

secondary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline newborn HR using the scare ventilator at 40 cpm
secondary_outcome.time_frame: pre-intervention, ten minutes after intervention starts and every ten minutes for 2 hours straight
secondary_outcome.description: differences in HR mean with two tales of statistical analysis ,between the two study periods

secondary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline on Sleep-wake cycles (SWC) using the scare ventilator at 20 cpm
secondary_outcome.time_frame: pre-intervention, ten minutes after intervention starts and every ten minutes for 2 hours straight
secondary_outcome.description: % of time of aEEG SWC presence, two tales of statistical differences, between the 2 study periods

secondary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline on Sleep-wake cycles (SWC) using the scare ventilator at 40 cpm
secondary_outcome.time_frame: pre-intervention, ten minutes after intervention starts and every ten minutes for 2 hours straight
secondary_outcome.description: % of time of aEEG SWC presence, two tales of statistical differences, between the 2 study periods

secondary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline on Discomfort scale using the scare ventilator at 20 cpm
secondary_outcome.time_frame: pre-intervention, ten minutes after intervention starts every ten minutes for 2 hours straight
secondary_outcome.description: Differences with the NIPS average, two tales of statistical differences, between the two study periods (scale 0-12; 0-2 no pain, 3-4 moderate pain, 5 or more severe pain)

secondary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline on Discomfort scale using the scare ventilator at 40 cpm
secondary_outcome.time_frame: pre-intervention, ten minutes after intervention starts every ten minutes for 2 hours straight
secondary_outcome.description: Differences with the NIPS average, two tales of statistical differences, between the two study periods (scale 0-12; 0-2 no pain, 3-4 moderate pain, 5 or more severe pain)

secondary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline on RR using the scare ventilator at 20 cpm
secondary_outcome.time_frame: pre-intervention, ten minutes after intervention starts every ten minutes for 2 hours straight
secondary_outcome.description: differences in RR mean with two tales of statistical differences between the two periods

secondary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline on RR using the scare ventilator at 40 cpm
secondary_outcome.time_frame: pre-intervention, ten minutes after intervention starts every ten minutes for 2 hours straight
secondary_outcome.description: differences in RR mean with two tales of statistical differences between the two periods

secondary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline on oxygen saturation using the scare ventilator at 20 cpm
secondary_outcome.time_frame: pre-intervention, ten minutes after intervention starts every ten minutes for 2 hours straight
secondary_outcome.description: differences in mean oxygen saturation expressed as a % , with two tales of statistical differences between the two periods

secondary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline on oxygen saturation using the scare ventilator at 40 cpm
secondary_outcome.time_frame: pre-intervention, ten minutes after intervention starts every ten minutes for 2 hours straight
secondary_outcome.description: differences in mean oxygen saturation expressed as a % , with two tales of statistical differences between the two periods

arm_group.description: Preterm babies, healthy at the time of the study , free of neonatal diseases and/or sequelae or malformations or genetic diseases
Term healthy babies, without respiratory and/or cardiovascular malformations or genetic diseases

intervention.description: To set scare ventilator by 20 cycles per minute
To set scare ventilator by 40 cycles per minute

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- hospitalized healthy term or preterm babies,
- weighing more than 1500g at the time of the study
Exclusion Criteria:
- babies receiving any respiratory support
- carrier of any mayor malformation or genetic condition
